awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: A Simulation Tool to Teach Cybersecurity and Digital Fluency
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a software platform for K-12 that helps to educate young and vulnerable students about cyber threats.  In addition, the proposed platform is designed to assist K-12 teachers to effectively communicate safe practices with students where the teachers do not have previous professional training in this area. This proposed tool for cyber security education also may provide value to a wide range of institutions within academia, industry, and government. Providing knowledge and training in a secure environment may increase the effectiveness of cybersecurity and digital fluency practices. By empowering and educating the next generation workforce, it may be possible to mitigate potential threats to businesses and institutions that are at risk of security breaches. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an education software platform that teaches cyber security awareness and protects against cyber threats aimed at K-12 students. One of the most prevalent of threats is identity theft, which affects millions of individuals annually, costing billions of dollars and emotional distress to the victims. Given the proliferation of social media, privacy education is essential to address the potential dangers facing the billions of people using these platforms. Because social media users span a wide range of demographics, there has been a lack of effective education methods and standards for increasing user awareness. The proposed technology uses a simple, cost-effective tool to teach cybersecurity and digital fluency practices regardless of user age and background. The technology is designed to provide value to all individuals with a social media presence, where account hacking or identity theft could have financial and/or social ramifications. The proposed initial target - the primary education system - may provide the greatest value to society as children are just entering the social media environment and are thought to be the most vulnerable and in need of privacy education. Early privacy awareness education may provide a solid foundation to successfully navigate current and future cybersecurity challenges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we interviewed almost 200 individuals from the K-12 education system across The United States with the focus on New York state.
We interviewed a wide-range of decision makers, influencers, end-users, etc. and concluded the following 4 points as the summary of our customer discovery process:1- The educators have limited time to teach Cybersecurity to the kids and they're already overwhelmed with many subjects to teach.
2-  The educators don't have sufficient knowledge themselves about the subject and don't have time to learn it (unlike math and science that they have taught for years and know them well).
3- There are no tools available to teach about cybersecurity and they have to rely on old models like giving the students a list of Dos and Don'ts or show them pictures or videos which are ineffective.
4- Simulation-based teaching seems to be the right-way to teach about this subject.
These findings helped us apply for NSF STTR Phase I and develop an MVP called DigitalPASS that helped us address the pain points brought up by the interviewees in this iCorps grant.

Knowing the education ecosystem helped us better understand the needs of the individuals and also gave us good ideas on how to approach other customer segments that might have similar pain points such as defense, health care, etc who are targets to cyber attacks as the adversaries want to attack our national interest.
